item.title: Iraq Truck Bomb Kills 33 at Checkpoint Near Babylonian Ruins
item.description: More than 100 people were injured when a driver detonated a fuel truck in the city of Hilla.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: OMAR AL-JAWOSHY
item.media:description: Residents gathered at the site of a suicide bombing on Sunday at a checkpoint in Hilla, Iraq, south of Baghdad.

item.title: Editorial: Leaving the E.U. Would Hurt Britain’s Economy
item.description: Trade with member nations and the rest of the world would become more difficult, as new agreements and regulations would be needed.
item.dc:creator: THE EDITORIAL BOARD

item.title: Egypt Says Muslim Brotherhood, Backed by Hamas, Killed Top Prosecutor
item.description: The assassination of Hisham Barakat in June prompted Cairo to introduce a sweeping antiterrorism law that expanded government powers and restricted civil liberties.
item.dc:creator: NOUR YOUSSEF

item.title: Iran Sentences Billionaire to Death for Corruption
item.description: Babak Zanjani and two associates were convicted of corruption involving oil sales during the administration of former President Mahmoud Ahmadinejad.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS
item.media:description: Babak Zanjani in court on Sunday in Tehran.

item.title: 25 Migrants Drown Off Turkey, Few Allowed Into Macedonia
item.description: At least 25 people drowned off the Turkish coast while trying to reach Greece on Sunday, while Macedonian authorities imposed further restrictions on refugees trying to cross the Greek border.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Milan Journal: Italian Cuisine Worth Going to Prison For
item.description: InGalera, a restaurant that opened recently to rave reviews, is inside the Bollate Penitentiary on the outskirts of the city.
item.dc:creator: JIM YARDLEY
item.media:credit: Gianni Cipriano for The New York Times
item.media:description: Prison movie posters on the walls at InGalera, at the Bollate penitentiary in Milan, as an inmate serves patrons.

item.title: Slovakia’s Governing Party Loses Majority as Far Right Makes Gains
item.description: Prime Minister Robert Fico could face obstacles in forming a government after the rise of far-right extremists.
item.dc:creator: MIROSLAVA GERMANOVA
item.media:description: Prime Minister Robert Fico in Bratislava, Slovakia, on Sunday.

item.title: Suicide Attack Kills at Least 47 South of Iraqi Capital
item.description: A suicide bomber rammed his explosives-laden fuel truck into a security checkpoint south of Baghdad on Sunday, killing at least 47 people and wounding dozens, officials said.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Iran Sentences Tycoon to Death for Corruption
item.description: An Iranian court has sentenced a well-known tycoon to death for corruption linked to oil sales during the rule of former President Mahmoud Ahmadinejad, the judiciary spokesman said Sunday.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS
item.media:description: Babak Zanjani in court on Sunday in Tehran.

item.title: Philippines Will Impound Ship Linked to North Korea
item.description: A cargo vessel linked to North Korea was seized under United Nations sanctions intended to punish it for recent nuclear and rocket tests.
item.dc:creator: FLOYD WHALEY
item.media:description: The MV Jin Teng after its arrival on Thursday at Subic Bay in the Philippines. Philippine officials, believing the ship to be North Korean, have taken steps to impound it.

item.title: Men in Police Garb Kill 10 in Honduras
item.description: Five men arrived in a vehicle at a billiards hall in the Honduran capital of Tegucigalpa and shot and killed at least eight people, and injured others, two of who later died.
item.dc:creator: REUTERS

item.title: Alumni of Britain’s Elite Schools
item.description: A sampling of some of the alumni — in common parlance, “old boys” and “old girls” (but mostly boys) — who have made names for themselves.
item.dc:creator: PALKO KARASZ
item.media:description: Eton College, a boys’ school just outside London, was founded by King Henry VI in 1440.

item.title: Britain’s Exclusive Schools Try to Be a Little Less So
item.description: Few institutions better symbolize social stratification and privilege in Britain than its top independent schools. Some of them are trying to remedy that.
item.dc:creator: STEPHEN CASTLE
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.media:description: Students at Rugby School in Rugby, one of the elite British institutions that critics say help perpetuate the country’s class divide.

item.title: South Korea Government Accused of Using Defamation Laws to Silence Critics
item.description: Such laws carry penalties of up to seven years in prison — even for comments that are true, if they are deemed not to be in the public interest.
item.dc:creator: CHOE SANG-HUN
item.media:credit: Jean Chung for The New York Times
item.media:description: Park Sung-su, a political activist, protesting in front of the Supreme Court in Seoul, South Korea, last month. The sign, in Korean, reads, “Bite it off, you dogs of power.” Mr. Park was freed in December after being jailed on charges of defaming the president.

item.title: Taliban Say They Won’t Attend Peace Talks, but Officials Aren’t Convinced
item.description: Afghan and Pakistani government officials expect negotiations to continue, but pushed the start date back to sometime later this month.
item.dc:creator: ROD NORDLAND and MUJIB MASHAL

item.title: News Analysis: The World Has a Problem: Too Many Young People
item.description: They may put pressure on the global economy, sow political unrest and spur mass migration.
item.dc:creator: SOMINI SENGUPTA
item.media:description: Unemployed Indians handed in paperwork at a government employment office in 2012.

item.title: Hassan al-Turabi, Islamist Who Championed Bin Laden, Dies at 84
item.description: After the expulsion of Al Qaeda from Sudan, his home country, in 1996, Mr. Turabi sought to reposition himself as a mainstream politician.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Serbia Dissolves Parliament and Calls Early Elections
item.description: The government said it needed a new mandate to pursue the economic changes that it deems essential for the country to join the European Union.
item.dc:creator: DAN BILEFSKY
item.media:description: President Tomislav Nikolic of Serbia signed the measure to dissolve Parliament in Belgrade on Friday.

item.title: Turkey Seizes Newspaper, Zaman, as Press Crackdown Continues
item.description: The move highlighted President Recep Tayyip Erdogan’s campaign against opposition journalists and the followers of Fethullah Gulen, a cleric.
item.dc:creator: SAFAK TIMUR and TIM ARANGO
item.media:credit: Selman Gunes / Zaman Daily News / Handout/European Pressphoto Agency
item.media:description: The police dispersed opponents of President Recep Tayyip Erdogan on Friday during a raid on the Zaman newspaper in Istanbul.

item.title: Money Given to Kenya, Since Stolen, Puts Nike in Spotlight
item.description: According to email exchanges, letters, bank records and invoices, Nike’s attempt to maintain sponsorship of Kenya’s runners has precipitated a scandal.
item.dc:creator: JEFFREY GETTLEMAN
item.media:description: Kenyan runners, feared by rivals from other countries, training in the Rift Valley north of Nairobi in January.
